Award.AwardTitle: The California State University, East Bay Noyce Teaching Fellowship Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The College of Science and the College of Education and Allied Studies at California State University, East Bay (CSUEB), the Alameda County Office of Education (ACOE), the Stephen D. Bechtel Jr. Foundation, and the Edward Teller Foundation are collaborators on the CSUEB Noyce Teaching Fellowship program. This program increases the number of highly qualified science and mathematics students who obtain a teaching credential and master's degree at CSUEB. It provides scholarships for the first credential/master's year and salary supplements for the subsequent four teaching years for two cohorts of eight Fellows. These sixteen Noyce Fellows complete an innovative cohort-based teacher preparation program, acquire laboratory experience and take advantage of a professional support network and mentoring, which helps them to succeed as teachers in high-need school districts. Throughout the program and into the Fellows' first teaching years, ACOE provides state-of-the-art professional development, in order to retain these new teachers who possess exemplary depth of mathematical and/or scientific content knowledge.

Science fellows complete the Master's program that is jointly offered by the Department of Teacher Education at CSUEB and the Edward Teller Educational Center at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (LLNL). Partnering with the LLNL provides rigorous scientific training to this group of nascent teachers. This Master's program offers students graduate credit for participation in three summer seminars taught by laboratory scientists and other professionals at LLNL. During the 4th seminar, students are paired with an LLNL scientist with whom they conduct research for 6-7 weeks daily; this typically results in a publication or poster which may appear in a national, refereed journal. Mathematics fellows complete the Master's in Teacher Education, Option in Curriculum at CSUEB.

The CSUB Noyce Teaching Fellowship program recognizes that successful teachers must be able to adapt their teaching methods to meet the demands of diverse learning styles in the classroom. Therefore, the CSUEB program is structured to enable students to combine core knowledge and effective teaching methods that will produce successful learning experiences. The Noyce Fellowships support students in CSUEB teacher preparation and Master's programs that promote teamwork, leadership and problem solving and cultivate professional experiences that are designed to strengthen competence, enhance self-confidence and increase the likelihood of committing to teaching as a career.

The Noyce Teaching Fellows are expected to become leaders within their schools and districts and furnish the tools that will enable underrepresented groups to be competitive within the increasingly mathematical, scientific and technical workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
California State University East Bay, Noyce ScholarsTeaching Fellows Program

Outcomes - Intellectual Merit:  The California State University, East Bay, Noyce Teaching Fefllowship program supported 18 fellows who completed their 5th year credential program and 16 of which have completed their master's degree.  Sample Master's projects are attached. The two remaining fellows expect to complete their master's by June 2018. During the grant period, so far, 11 fellows have completed their four year teaching committment.  With a full time teaching load, these 11 fellows served over 5 X 30 X 11 = 1,650 students per year for 4 years in high needs schools. The remaining fellows will continue to teach in high needs schools for several years impacting over 1000 students each year.  Additionally many of the fellows who have completed their teaching committment continue to teach in high needs schools. The evaluation research has informed the program’s practice and has been disseminated through presentations and websites.

All of the Noyce Fellows completed the CSUEB teacher preparation program that promotes teamwork, leadership and problem solving. This program cultivates professional experiences, including a variety of field experiences integrated with academic and pedagogical preparation, which are designed to strengthen competence, enhance self-confidence and increase the likelihood of coming to teaching as a career. Each fellow participated in at least two professional development workshops for the first year of their fellowship and most of the fellows chose to continue to participate in professional development workshops in subsequent years. All of the science credential students at CSUEB are provided with memberships to the NSTA and the math credential students are provided with memberships to the NCTM.  Mentoring relationships were established for the fellows formally for two years and many of these relationships continue. 

This program has produced dedicated and skilled math and science teaching professionals.  The external evaluator noted:  "The teaching experience, especially in an age of under-funded schools and weakened social and economic support for schools, is difficult and often frustrating work. In the face of the challenges, Teacher Fellows clearly demonstrated dedication and determination to meet high standards of professionalism, and have been well received in the schools where they have done their student teaching, and where, eventually, most were employed. Their supervisors are well pleased with their teaching performance, and Noyce Fellows have become thoroughly dedicated, caring teachers." 

Outcomes - Broader Impacts:  The East Bay Area of San Francisco, which includes Alameda and Contra Costa Counties, consists of an extremely ethnically diverse population. STEM professionals are in high demand, but there are significant long-term shortages in the workforce of those possessing competence in science and mathematics. The future economic health of the region depends increasingly on an educational system capable of preparing science and math teachers to respond successfully to the demand for STEM teachers and the needs of students who require intensive and effective educational programs in science and mathematics. The Noyce Teaching Fellows are highly effective teachers within their schools and districts and furnish the tools that will enable underrepresented groups to be competitive within the increasingly mathematical, scientific and technical workforce.  These fellows will serve over 100 students each year to increase their math and science skills and help them prepare for their STEM futures.
